I don’t believe in girls going to college with the men and cramming their heads full of Latin and Greek and all that nonsense.”“Not a bit of it. I shall thrive on it. Oh
column18: I’m not going to overdo things. As ‘Josiah Allen’s wife
column19: ’ says
column20: I shall be ‘mejum’. But I’ll have lots of spare time in the long winter evenings
column21: and I’ve no vocation for fancy work. I’m going to teach over at Carmody
column22: you know.”

column1: “So they did. But as soon as Gilbert heard that you had applied for it he went to them--they had a business meeting at the school last night
column2: you know--and told them that he withdrew his application
column3: and suggested that they accept yours. He said he was going to teach at White Sands. Of course he knew how much you wanted to stay with Marilla
column4: and I must say I think it was real kind and thoughtful in him
column5: that’s what. Real self-sacrificing
column6: too
column7: for he’ll have his board to pay at White Sands
column8: and everybody knows he’s got to earn his own way through college. So the trustees decided to take you. I was tickled to death when Thomas came home and told me.”“I guess you can’t prevent him now. He’s signed papers with the White Sands trustees. So it wouldn’t do him any good now if you were to refuse. Of course you’ll take the school. You’ll get along all right
column9: now that there are no Pyes going. Josie was the last of them
column10: and a good thing she was
column11: that’s what. There’s been some Pye or other going to Avonlea school for the last twenty years
column12: and I guess their mission in life was to keep school teachers reminded that earth isn’t their home. Bless my heart! What does all that winking and blinking at the Barry gable mean?”Anne went to the little Avonlea graveyard the next evening to put fresh flowers on Matthew’s grave and water the Scotch rosebush. She lingered there until dusk
column13: liking the peace and calm of the little place
column14: with its poplars whose rustle was like low
column15: friendly speech
column16: and its whispering grasses growing at will among the graves. When she finally left it and walked down the long hill that sloped to the Lake of Shining Waters it was past sunset and all Avonlea lay before her in a dreamlike afterlight--“a haunt of ancient peace.” There was a freshness in the air as of a wind that had blown over honey-sweet fields of clover. Home lights twinkled out here and there among the homestead trees. Beyond lay the sea
column17: misty and purple
column18: with its haunting
column19: unceasing murmur. The west was a glory of soft mingled hues
column20: and the pond reflected them all in still softer shadings. The beauty of it all thrilled Anne’s heart
column21: and she gratefully opened the gates of her soul to it.Halfway down the hill a tall lad came whistling out of a gate before the Blythe homestead. It was Gilbert
column22: and the whistle died on his lips as he recognized Anne. He lifted his cap courteously
column23: but he would have passed on in silence
column24: if Anne had not stopped and held out her hand.“We are going to be the best of friends
column25: ” said Gilbert
column26: jubilantly. “We were born to be good friends
column27: Anne. You’ve thwarted destiny enough. I know we can help each other in many ways. You are going to keep up your studies
column28: aren’t you? So am I. Come
column29: I’m going to walk home with you.”
